history.content:
Since you say you're "trying to avoid taking any class that involves heavy coding next semester," I'd say go with the CS 70 option. 61C projects can be very time-consuming and heavy in workload; on the other hand, there isn't a line of code to write in CS 70 (that isn't to say 70 isn't time-consuming; those problem sets can take a VERY long time).

But, in the context of your schedule, a lot of your classes are "problem set heavy" rather than "project heavy." While I can't speak on 16B since I never took it, but Math 53 and R1B also have very time-consuming (computationally for 53 since you should be doing all the HW problems to do well on the exams, and R1B papers just straight up take a long time with research, reading, and writing) assignments. So, it could be better for you to go with 61C to balance out the type of workload you have.


I wouldn't say there's a significant difference in the amount of work between the 70 option vs. 61C option though, so you should expect to spend the same amount of time for both options. In my opinion, it comes down to if you'd rather have a "problem set heavy" workload, or a more rounded "half problem set, half project heavy" schedule. 

-----------------------------------

Wanted to add an opinion on 16B. HW is generally psets which are not difficult if you keep up with lecture. The final project (if its still SIXTEEN) can be very time-consuming, depending on a variety of factors. When I took 16B last semester I went to extra labs on every weekend they were offered to get it done.

children.subject: 70 + 16b + 53 + R1B is a thick workload mate. gl

history.content:
Hello,

Can someone comment on my probable course-load for next semester?  Is it advisable to replace CS70, with CS61C? (Am trying to avoid taking any class that involves heavy coding next semester, but will greatly appreciate any input on this)
history.subject: CS70 (Or CS61C), Math 53, EE 16B, HSS (R1B)
